Faraday Copper currently trades on a P/B of 20.9x, with the last close at CA$5.39, which sits well above the peer and industry benchmarks in the data.

P/B compares the share price to the book value of equity per share, so it is often used for asset heavy sectors like metals and mining, where balance sheet assets and reserves matter more than near term earnings. For Faraday Copper, this high P/B multiple is sitting against a backdrop of no reported revenue, a net loss of CA$25.97m and forecasts that the company will remain unprofitable over the next three years.

data.title: Wilmar International (SGX:F34) Margin Improvement Challenges Cautious Community Narratives
data.description:
Advertisement

Wilmar International FY 2025 earnings snapshot

Wilmar International (SGX:F34) has kicked off FY 2025 with first half revenue of about US$32.9b and basic EPS of US$0.095, setting the tone for how the rest of the year could shape up for margins and profitability. The company has seen half year revenue move from roughly US$30.9b and EPS of US$0.093 in 1H 2024 to US$36.4b and EPS of about US$0.094 in 2H 2024, before reaching the latest 1H 2025 levels. This gives investors a clear view of how the top and bottom line have been tracking through recent periods. That backdrop, together with an improvement in net profit margin to 2.0%, frames these results as a check in on how efficiently Wilmar is converting its sales base into lasting profitability.

See our full analysis for Wilmar International.

With the headline numbers on the table, the next step is to see how this earnings profile lines up with the widely shared narratives around Wilmar's growth prospects, risks, and longer term margin story.

Curious how numbers become stories that shape markets? Explore Community Narratives

Trailing 12â€‘month profit reaches about US$1.4b

  • Over the last 12 months, Wilmar generated about US$70.4b in revenue and around US$1.4b in net income, which works out to a 2.0% net profit margin compared with 1.7% a year earlier.
  • What stands out for a more optimistic view is that trailing earnings grew 20.6% over the past year even though the five year trend shows an average 8.6% decline each year. As a result, recent profit strength sits alongside a much weaker longer term record.
    • This recent period shows net income at roughly US$1.4b on US$70.4b of sales, while the longer run data points to a multi year earnings decline, so anyone with a bullish angle needs to square that contrast.
    • At the same time, the 2.0% margin is still quite thin in absolute terms, which means even small changes in costs or pricing can move profit up or down quite quickly.

Stronger recent margins and earnings growth give bulls some evidence to point to, but the longer multi year earnings decline keeps the story more balanced than a simple recovery narrative suggests. ðŸ“Š Read the what the Community is saying about Wilmar International.

P/E of 12.3x sits between sector and peers

  • Wilmar trades on a P/E of 12.3x, which is cheaper than the Asian Food industry average of 16.1x but higher than a peer group average of 9.9x, so it sits in the middle of the pack on this simple earnings multiple.
  • Critics highlight that even with this mid range P/E, there are clear financial pressure points, especially around interest coverage and dividends, that could justify the market keeping the shares on a discount to some food peers.
    • The data flags that interest payments are not well covered by earnings, which can make a 12.3x multiple feel less comfortable than it looks against the wider industry at 16.1x.
    • The dividend track record is described as unstable and dividend sustainability a concern, so income focused investors may treat the current yield and multiple more cautiously than a simple P/E comparison suggests.

DCF fair value sits well above the current price

  • The current share price of S$3.52 is well below a DCF fair value estimate of about S$6.60, and the dataset also notes that this implies the shares trade roughly 46.7% below that modelled value.
  • Supporters of a more positive stance point to that DCF gap and the 20.6% trailing earnings growth as reasons to consider the stock undervalued, while the same numbers also sit alongside modest forecast growth of about 3.6% a year for earnings and 4.6% a year for revenue, which keeps expectations relatively low.
    • The projected 3.6% earnings growth is below the Singapore marketâ€™s expected 7.5% earnings growth, so the DCF upside does not come with especially strong growth assumptions in these forecasts.
    • Because the net margin is 2.0% on roughly US$70.4b of trailing revenue, even modest growth in sales or small margin shifts can move absolute profit by hundreds of millions of US$, which partly explains why a valuation model can land so far above the current share price.

Next Steps

Don't just look at this quarter; the real story is in the long-term trend. We've done an in-depth analysis on Wilmar International's growth and its valuation to see if today's price is a bargain. Add the company to your watchlist or portfolio now so you don't miss the next big move.

data.title: Is Campbell Soup (CPB) Now Offering Value After Prolonged Share Price Weakness
data.description:
• If you are wondering whether Campbell's current share price still reflects the value of a classic consumer brand, you are not alone. This article is built to help you size that up calmly.
  • At a last close of US$26.86, the stock has seen a 0.4% decline over 7 days, a 1.9% decline over 30 days, and is down 3.1% year to date, with a 29.2% decline over 1 year and a 42.5% decline over 3 years.
  • These moves sit against an ongoing stream of news around packaged food companies, including debates on pricing power, consumer demand for at home meals, and brand relevance in crowded supermarket aisles. For Campbell's, those themes shape how investors think about its earnings resilience and what they are willing to pay for the stock.
  • Simply Wall St currently gives Campbell's a valuation score of 4/6, based on how it screens across several checks for being undervalued. Next, we will walk through the main valuation methods used here before finishing with a broader way to think about what that score really means over the long run.

Find out why Campbell's's -29.2% return over the last year is lagging behind its peers.

Advertisement

Approach 1: Campbell's Discounted Cash Flow (DCF) Analysis

A Discounted Cash Flow, or DCF, model estimates what a business could be worth by projecting its future cash flows and then discounting them back to today using a required rate of return. It is essentially asking what those future dollars are worth in today's terms.

For Campbell's, the model used is a 2 Stage Free Cash Flow to Equity approach based on cash flow projections. The last twelve months free cash flow is reported at about $658.3 million. Analysts supply forecasts for the next few years, and Simply Wall St then extends those further, with ten year projections reaching $881.2 million in 2035, all in $ terms.

When all those projected cash flows are discounted back, the model arrives at an estimated intrinsic value of about $59.35 per share. Compared with the recent share price of $26.86, this implies a 54.7% discount to that DCF estimate. This suggests that Campbell's may be trading below this particular assessment of its cash flow value.

Result: UNDERVALUED

Our Discounted Cash Flow (DCF) analysis suggests Campbell's is undervalued by 54.7%. Track this in your watchlist or portfolio, or discover 54 more high quality undervalued stocks.

Head to the Valuation section of our Company Report for more details on how we arrive at this Fair Value for Campbell's.

Approach 2: Campbell's Price vs Earnings

For a profitable business like Campbell's, the P/E ratio is a useful shorthand for how much investors are paying for each dollar of current earnings. It captures what the market is willing to pay today for those earnings, without needing detailed forecasts.

What counts as a "normal" P/E depends a lot on how investors view a company's growth prospects and risk. Higher expected growth or perceived resilience can justify a higher multiple, while slower growth or higher risk usually pulls it down.

Campbell's currently trades on a P/E of 13.9x, compared with a Food industry average of 24.5x and a peer group average of 13.2x. Simply Wall St also calculates a proprietary "Fair Ratio" of 20.7x for Campbell's, which is the P/E level it might trade on given its earnings profile, industry, profit margins, market cap and specific risks.

This Fair Ratio can be more tailored than a simple comparison to peers or the broad industry, because it adjusts for the factors that make Campbell's different rather than assuming all companies deserve the same multiple. Set against the current P/E of 13.9x, the 20.7x Fair Ratio describes Campbell's shares as screening as undervalued on this metric.

Result: UNDERVALUED

P/E ratios tell one story, but what if the real opportunity lies elsewhere? Start investing in legacies, not executives. Discover our 19 top founder-led companies.

Upgrade Your Decision Making: Choose your Campbell's Narrative

Earlier we mentioned that there is an even better way to understand valuation, so let's introduce you to Narratives, which are simply your story about Campbell's, linked directly to your own revenue, earnings and margin assumptions, a Fair Value estimate, and then compared with the current share price to help you decide what to do.

On Simply Wall St's Community page, Narratives are an accessible tool used by millions of investors that let you combine your qualitative view on things like scanner trends, tariffs, product relevance, snacks and meals demand, or cost savings with a structured financial forecast so your opinion is tied to actual numbers rather than vibes alone.

Narratives are refreshed as new news, analyst targets, earnings updates, or guidance changes are entered into the model. As a result, your Fair Value view moves with the information, and you can quickly see if your story still lines up with how Campbell's is trading.

For Campbell's, one investor might build a Narrative closer to the higher Fair Value views around US$55.33 that lean on stronger Snacks, premium products and supply chain efficiency. Another might sit near the more cautious US$26.00 Fair Value that leans on pressure from private labels, tariffs and slower processed food demand. Both investors can see in real time how their Fair Value compares to the current price.

For Campbell's, however, we will make it really easy for you with previews of two leading Campbell's Narratives:

  • They build in rising profit margins over the next few years, supported by cost-savings programs, supply chain work and focused marketing on brands such as Rao's and Goldfish.
  • The result is a consensus price target of US$34.58 that sits close to where shares are trading in this view, which they frame as broadly in line with their estimate of fair value.

data.title: HP Q1 Beat Highlights AI PC Momentum And Memory Cost Challenge
data.description:
• HP Inc. (NYSE:HPQ) reported fiscal Q1 2026 results with Personal Systems net revenue growth and AI PCs making up more than one third of shipments.
  • The company faced a sharp jump in memory costs, roughly doubling over the quarter, which pressured margins.
  • Management responded with cost mitigation moves, including product redesigns, supply agreements, and selective pricing actions, while continuing to return capital to shareholders.

For investors watching NYSE:HPQ, the latest quarter pairs operational pressure with clear traction in AI PCs. The stock trades at $18.81 and is down 15.0% year to date and 40.7% over the past year, reflecting a tough stretch despite the progress in newer product categories.

Looking ahead, the key questions for you are how effectively HP manages elevated memory costs and whether AI PC demand remains strong enough to support margins. The companyâ€™s focus on redesigning products, adjusting pricing, and locking in supply terms will be central to how these Q1 trends develop over the coming quarters.

Stay updated on the most important news stories for HP by adding it to your watchlist or portfolio. Alternatively, explore our Community to discover new perspectives on HP.

See which insiders are buying and buying and selling HP following this latest news.

For current and prospective shareholders, this Q1 update sends a mixed but useful signal. On one hand, HP outperformed expectations on both revenue and EPS, with net revenue of US$14.4b compared to US$13.5b a year earlier and non GAAP EPS above consensus. On the other, operating income fell and management is guiding toward the lower end of its full year earnings ranges as DRAM and NAND costs pressure margins. That combination often leads to short term share price weakness, which you are already seeing. However, it also gives you clearer information on how management plans to handle higher input costs through product re configuration, supplier diversification and selective price increases. The fact that HP maintained its fiscal 2026 GAAP EPS range of US$2.47 to US$2.77 while outlining a US$1b cost savings plan suggests management is trying to balance investment in AI PCs with disciplined capital returns, including US$0.6b returned in Q1 and continued buybacks. Against a backdrop of insider share sales and mixed institutional flows, this quarter is likely to be read as a test of whether HP can convert strong AI PC demand into durable earnings power rather than just a one off beat.

How This Fits Into The HP Narrative

  • The strong Q1, with AI PCs at more than one third of shipments and Personal Systems growth, supports the narrative that AI driven PCs and premium devices can underpin revenue and margin resilience.
  • The sharp rise in memory costs and guidance toward the low end of EPS ranges challenges the view that cost restructuring alone can fully offset input cost pressure and structural headwinds in Print.
  • The specific memory cost inflation and the US$1b mitigation plan through FY2028 add more detail on cost risks and timing that are only partially reflected in the existing narrative about restructuring and supply chain diversification.

  • âš ï¸ Analysts and risk models highlight four key risk factors, including negative shareholdersâ€™ equity and concerns around dividend stability and leverage, which may limit how aggressive HP can be with buybacks and payouts.
  • ðŸŽ AI PCs already account for over 35% of shipments, supporting the view that HP can benefit if the PC refresh cycle and demand for higher spec devices continue to support the Personal Systems segment.
  • ðŸŽ Management is pursuing US$1b in gross run rate savings by FY2028 and has continued to return capital through buybacks and dividends, which some investors may see as supportive of per share metrics if executed carefully.

What To Watch Going Forward

From here, you may want to track three things closely. First, how quickly memory cost inflation stabilises or is offset through supplier agreements, product design changes and pricing. Second, whether AI PC growth remains strong enough to support revenue and operating margins, especially compared with peers like Dell, Lenovo and Apple in higher end PCs. Third, how capital allocation evolves, including the pace of buybacks after repurchasing 13.3m shares in the latest quarter and any shift in dividend policy, given the balance sheet risk indicators.
